diagnoses.name: Acute Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the glomeruli, which are the parts of the kidney that filter blood. It can lead to symptoms such as edema, particularly in the feet, and can cause abnormalities in urine, such as pyuria.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and heart valves. It often causes fever, heart murmurs, petechiae, anemia, and can result in leukocytosis as the body responds to the infection.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, leading to symptoms such as enlarged lymph nodes, anemia, and can sometimes cause leukocytosis depending on the body's response.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. It can cause anemia, leukocytosis, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Kidney Infection (Pyelonephritis)
diagnoses.description: A type of urinary tract infection that can ascend from the bladder to the kidneys. It can cause symptoms like pyuria, fever, and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. It can lead to heart problems, arthritis, and skin lesions.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Symptoms can include enlarged lymph nodes, anemia, and night sweats.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including anemia, leukocytosis, lymphadenopathy, and renal involvement that could lead to edema.

diagnoses.name: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
diagnoses.description: A condition in which a blood clot forms in a deep vein, usually in the legs, which can cause swelling or edema in the affected limb. Complications can include pulmonary embolism.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include swollen lymph nodes, fatigue, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including autoimmune hemolysis, fever, neuropsychiatric manifestations (such as delirium), acute pericarditis, and alopecia. SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own tissues.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for affecting the joints, rheumatoid arthritis can have systemic effects, including fever, pericarditis, and very rarely, autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory condition is characterized by fever, arthritis, and a salmon-colored rash. It may also sometimes result in pericarditis and alopecia; however, autoimmune hemolysis is less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This rare autoimmune disorder is characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia. Other systemic symptoms like fever can occur, but pericarditis, delirium, and alopecia are less characteristic.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can cause a wide spectrum of symptoms, including fever, delirium (due to encephalitis or systemic effects), and more rarely, pericarditis or alopecia. Direct viral infection leading to autoimmune hemolysis is rare but may occur indirectly through immune-mediated mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Paraneoplastic Syndromes
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of cancer can trigger immune responses that affect the body in various ways, such as causing autoimmune hemolysis, fever, and occasionally, neuropsychiatric symptoms (paraneoplastic encephalitis), pericarditis, or alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This rare autoimmune disorder features signs and symptoms of a combination of other connective tissue diseases, including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, which can sometimes present with autoimmune hemolysis, fever, pericarditis, and alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome that manifests with fever, pericarditis, and potentially, alopecia. Although less common, drug-induced hemolytic anemia can mimic autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This inflammatory disease is marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It is associated with systemic symptoms that may include fever and alopecia. While delirium and autoimmune hemolysis are not typical, pericarditis may occur.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: This is an inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Systemic symptoms can include fever. While autoimmune hemolysis, delirium, acute pericarditis, and alopecia are less commonly associated with sarcoidosis, it can have a wide range of manifestations and should be considered in the differential.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with pleural effusion, autoimmune processes (including hemolysis), skin changes (including dyspigmentation), neuropsychiatric manifestations (including psychosis), and synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for causing synovitis, advanced cases can involve pleural effusions, autoimmune hemolysis, and skin changes; neuropsychiatric manifestations are less common.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Aside from its hallmark dry eyes and mouth, Sjögren's can involve lung manifestations (pleural effusion), skin discoloration, peripheral neuropathy (which could manifest with psychiatric symptoms), and joint involvement.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily associated with thrombosis and miscarriage, antiphospholipid syndrome can occasionally present with some of these symptoms as secondary manifestations or overlaps with other autoimmune diseases.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by skin rash (potentially involving dyspigmentation) and muscle weakness, it can also involve interstitial lung disease (which could correlate with pleural effusion), and it has been associated with an increased risk of malignancy which can manifest with various symptoms including psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Known for skin thickening and often dyspigmentation, systemic sclerosis can also cause pulmonary involvement (including pleural effusion), and sometimes synovitis. The autoimmune component can lead to hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease features symptoms of several connective tissue diseases including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, with patients potentially presenting with pleural effusion, skin changes, and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that combines autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) with immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) and sometimes autoimmune neutropenia. While the other symptoms are less directly connected, the autoimmune nature of the disease suggests a potential for overlapping syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: This disease can cause a wide range of symptoms, including skin changes and potentially affecting the lungs and joints, though neuropsychiatric and direct autoimmune hemolytic symptoms are less common.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV/AIDS can manifest a wide variety of symptoms including those affecting the skin, joints, and causing neuropsychiatric symptoms. Secondary autoimmune hemolysis is also possible in the context of opportunistic infections or as part of an immune reconstitution syndrome.

Evans syndrome (combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia)
Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Oral Cavity

diagnoses.name: Acute Bronchitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the bronchial tubes, often developing from a cold or other respiratory infection.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Non-epileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.description: Seizures that are not due to epilepsy but rather psychological stress.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A brain disorder marked by an ongoing pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono or kissing disease, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and characterized by fever, fatigue, swollen lymph nodes, and sore throat.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by feelings of worry, anxiety, or fear that are strong enough to interfere with one's daily activities.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Acute Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses that occurs with an infection from a virus, bacteria, or fungus.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria, transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a virus that attacks the body's immune system. If HIV is not treated, it can lead to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS).

diagnoses: Connective tissue diseases (e.g., Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)
Autoimmune disorders (Systemic lupus erythematosus, Antiphospholipid syndrome)
Myocardial Infarction or Ischemic Heart Disease

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can manifest a broad range of symptoms, including lymphadenopathy (swelling of the lymph nodes), oral leukoplakia, mood lability, and depression due to the impact of the disease and potentially its treatment on mental health.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can cause lymphadenopathy, oral ulcerations which might be confused with leukoplakia, mood swings, and depression, as part of its wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is a disease characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, including lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy), and can lead to depression and, less commonly, lesions that might resemble leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Lymphoma, a type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, often presents with lymphadenopathy. It can indirectly cause depression through its impact on the patient's health and mood lability through systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus)
diagnoses.description: Mononucleosis, typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, features symptoms such as lymphadenopathy and can potentially lead to oral manifestations similar to leukoplakia. Mood swings and depression can occur as a result of the illness or the stress it causes.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: Syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection, can cause lymphadenopathy and oral leukoplakia-like lesions in its secondary stage. Mood lability and depression can occur as the disease progresses without treatment.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: Tuberculosis, an infectious disease primarily affecting the lungs, can cause lymphadenitis and lymphadenopathy. The chronic nature of the disease can contribute to depression.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL)
diagnoses.description: CLL is a type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that often leads to lymphadenopathy. It can indirectly cause depression and mood swings due to its effect on the patient’s overall health.

diagnoses.name: Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus Type I (HTLV-I)
diagnoses.description: HTLV-I infection can lead to lymphadenopathy and, in some cases, oral lesions similar to leukoplakia. Mood swings and depression can also be associated due to the condition or its complications.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that can cause lymphadenopathy. It may lead to depression due to the chronic nature of the disorder, and mood swings can be a part of the psychological impact.

diagnoses: Hypertensive Heart and Chronic Kidney Disease

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive crisis
diagnoses.description: An extremely high blood pressure that can lead to organ damage. Symptoms can include severe headache, nosebleeds (epistaxis), and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: A reaction to an allergen that can cause symptoms like angioedema, difficulty breathing, and cough.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing sudden swelling beneath the skin and other symptoms such as laryngeal edema.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to symptoms like fatigue, sore throat, fever, and possibly laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Upper respiratory infection
diagnoses.description: Infections affecting the nose, throat, and sinuses, leading to cough, sore throat, and potentially laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause angioedema, difficulty breathing, and laryngeal edema.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood or bone marrow characterized by an abnormal increase of white blood cells. It can cause symptoms like fatigue, nosebleeds, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In some cases, it can lead to complications such as Sjögren's syndrome, which affects the eyes.

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation or swelling of the tissue lining the sinuses that can lead to symptoms like cough, and in severe cases, vision problems and facial swelling.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include cough, vision problems, and skin lumps.

diagnoses: Nosebleeds (Epistaxis), primary and secondary to other conditions
Sleep Disorders, including Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA)
Neurological conditions, including Epilepsy and Seizure Disorders
Sinusitis and other upper respiratory infections
Eye Infections and Inflammations, such as Conjunctivitis

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by recurrent, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors (compulsions).

diagnoses.name: Common Cold
diagnoses.description: A viral infectious disease of the upper respiratory tract which primarily affects the nose (coryza is a common symptom).

diagnoses.name: Dyshidrotic Eczema
diagnoses.description: A type of eczema characterized by small blisters on the hands and feet. It's a skin condition that causes itchiness, redness, and flaking.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, kidneys, bladder, or urethra. It's more common in women than men.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders in which part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function normally, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). It can compromise the immune system, leading to an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). It interferes with your body's ability to fight infection and disease.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms. Coryza can be a symptom associated with it.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.description: Chronic stress can weaken the immune system, make skin conditions worse, and may be associated with mental health issues like OCD.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases caused by an overactive immune response against the body's own cells, leading to inflammation and damage. It can result in multiple symptoms including increased susceptibility to infections and skin conditions like eczema.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Hypermobility is a common feature.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It can also cause fatigue and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder in which your bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. This can also lead to anemia due to the imbalance of cell production.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by periods of illness, called flares, and periods of remission.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can also cause fatigue and widespread inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that may include symptoms of several diseases, including Sjögren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, and rheumatoid arthritis. It may present with features such as anemia and migratory edema.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Anemia caused by lack of iron, leading to a reduced number of red blood cells. Common symptoms include fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow cancer that disrupts the body's normal production of blood cells, leading to symptoms like anemia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition prevents the body from adequately producing red blood cells, leading to anemia. Can cause symptoms of fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, dry skin, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body, which could explain the broad range of symptoms including skin issues (dyshydrotic eczema), swelling (angioedema), and more serious conditions like interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic inflammatory disorders
diagnoses.description: Long-term inflammation in the body can lead to diverse symptoms, influencing skin health, lymph node size (lymphadenopathy), and potentially contributing to bladder problems and lipid imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity reactions
diagnoses.description: Reactions to allergens or irritants could potentially trigger eczema, angioedema, and lymphadenopathy, as well as possibly exacerbate symptoms of interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoproliferative disorders
diagnoses.description: These disorders involve the abnormal proliferation of lymphocytes, cells that are integral to the immune system, possibly leading to lymphadenopathy, and secondary skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A cluster of conditions that occur together, increasing the risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. Symptoms can include dyslipidemia. It doesn't directly cause the other conditions but could be associated due to underlying inflammatory processes.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV infection and progression to AIDS can lead to a wide variety of symptoms including lymphadenopathy, skin conditions, and other systemic symptoms due to immune system compromise.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing sudden swelling episodes (angioedema), which could indirectly relate to the cluster of symptoms specified if considering a broad spectrum of immune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, potentially accounting for this symptom profile.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that make tears and saliva, causing dryness but also systemic symptoms that may explain the skin and urinary symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate activation of mast cells which could lead to a variety of symptoms including skin lesions, angioedema, and possibly influence systemic symptoms such as those seen in dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when the loss of body fluids, mostly water, exceeds the amount that is taken in. Symptoms can include xerosis (dry skin) and presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period. Symptoms can include frequent urination, which can lead to a urinary tract infection, and can contribute to osteopenia due to changes in blood flow.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition involving an increased secretion of parathyroid hormone, which can lead to osteopenia due to the loss of calcium from bones and can contribute to urinary tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A group of symptoms that occur when there is damage to nerves that regulate nonvoluntary body functions, leading to blood pressure lability and potentially presyncope.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys do not work as well as they should, which can lead to osteopenia and can increase the risk of urinary tract infections due to changes in the urinary tract.

diagnoses.name: Addison’s Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the adrenal glands don’t produce enough hormones. Symptoms can include low blood pressure (contributing to presyncope) and skin changes like xerosis.

diagnoses.name: Hypothalamic Dysfunction
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the hypothalamus (a part of the brain that controls the pituitary gland) does not function properly. This dysfunction can affect the body's balance of water, electrolytes, and can lead to symptoms like xerosis and blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands responsible for keeping the eyes, mouth, and other parts of the body moist and lubricated, causing xerosis among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It's associated with autonomic dysfunction that can lead to urinary issues and lability in blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Renal Tubular Acidosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the kidneys fail to adequately filter metabolic acid, leading to a combination of symptoms including osteopenia, potential for urinary tract infections, and electrolyte imbalance that might contribute to presyncope.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. This can lead to thickened blood and increased risk of blood clots. Symptoms may include headaches, itching, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the body doesn't have enough iron to produce hemoglobin, leading to fatigue, weakness, and paleness. Could be related to the symptom of anemia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which exposure to everyday chemicals and pollutants, even at low levels, causes symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Pernicious Anemia
diagnoses.description: A decrease in red blood cells when the body can't absorb enough vitamin B12. Symptoms might include weakness, dysgeusia, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium spread by ticks. It often starts with a rash and can include symptoms like fatigue and joint pain. It might explain migratory patchy macular erythema.

diagnoses.name: Sweet's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A skin condition marked by fever and the rapid appearance of painful, inflamed, red or purple welts on the skin. Often accompanied by fever and leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Multiforme
diagnoses.description: A hypersensitivity reaction associated with certain infections, medications, and other triggers. It is characterized by target-like lesions on the skin.

diagnoses.name: Dermatitis Herpetiformis
diagnoses.description: A chronic blistering skin condition, characterized by blisters filled with a watery fluid. Despite its name, it is not related to herpes virus; it's associated with celiac disease.

diagnoses.name: Zinc Deficiency
diagnoses.description: It can lead to symptoms such as hair loss, diarrhea, and dysgeusia (distortion of the sense of taste). Linked with anemia and could potentially worsen chemical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, weakness, constipation, loss of appetite, and weight loss. Neurological changes, such as numbness and tingling in the hands and feet, can also occur.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hepatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Presents with elevated liver enzymes and can have symptoms like vomiting; autoimmune nature could explain decreased immunoglobulins and, indirectly, endometriosis through autoimmune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause vomiting and abnormal liver enzymes; its autoimmune nature could contribute to decreased immunoglobulins. Though there's no direct link to miscarriage or endometriosis, autoimmune diseases can have wide-ranging systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: A systemic autoimmune disease that can lead to decreased immunoglobulins, affect the liver, and potentially influence miscarriage risk. Though not directly causing vomiting, systemic symptoms can include gastrointestinal discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Hepatitis B or C
diagnoses.reasoning: Viral infections leading to chronic liver disease can explain abnormal liver enzymes and vomiting. The immune system's involvement could potentially relate to decreased immunoglobulins and indirectly affect reproductive health.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.reasoning: This autoimmune liver disease causes abnormal liver enzymes and could be associated with other autoimmune phenomena, including decreased immunoglobulins. Secondary complications could potentially influence miscarriage rates.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily explaining decreased immunoglobulins, some conditions in this category can lead to liver enzyme abnormalities and gastrointestinal symptoms like vomiting. The link to miscarriage and endometriosis would be more indirect, possibly due to increased infection risk.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.reasoning: This genetic disorder leads to iron overload, which can cause liver enzyme abnormalities and affect other organs. There's some evidence of a higher prevalence of endometriosis in patients, possibly related to oxidative stress.

diagnoses.name: Wilson's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: A rare inherited disorder causing copper accumulation, primarily affecting the liver but also potentially other organs. Symptoms can include vomiting and liver enzyme abnormalities. There's no direct link to decreased immunoglobulins, miscarriage, or endometriosis, but systemic diseases can have complex, indirect effects.

diagnoses.name: Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH)
diagnoses.reasoning: Part of the spectrum of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, it can explain the abnormal liver enzymes and, through complex metabolic and inflammatory pathways, might be tangentially connected to the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Alcoholism

A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms depend on the area of the brain affected, often including paralysis, speech problems, and confusion.
A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness.
An inflammation of the vestibular nerve, a nerve in the ear that helps control balance. This condition causes vertigo.
A type of migraine that presents primarily with vertigo along with migraine symptoms.
Disorders that affect the body's ability to process certain nutrients and vitamins, leading to symptoms such as vertigo, weakness, and tingling in the extremities.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like weakness, numbness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, leading to weakness, numbness, and coordination issues.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, including nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Damage to the nerves outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causing weakness, numbness, and pain.

diagnoses.name: Vertigo
diagnoses.description: A condition where a person feels as if they or the objects around them are moving when they are not. Often associated with nausea and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: Low blood sugar levels that can cause symptoms including weakness, shaking, sweating, hunger, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as paralysis, numbness, and sudden dizziness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to weakness and numbness that usually starts in the feet and legs and may spread to the upper body and arms.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This deficiency can lead to a form of anemia called pernicious anemia, causing weakness, numbness, difficulty walking, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, causing weakness, dizziness, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including severe headaches, nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headaches
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by a dull, aching pain and tightness in the forehead, scalp, or neck.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: Known for severe burning and piercing pain, they occur around or behind one eye or on one side of the face at a time. Swelling, redness, flushing, and sweating may occur on the side that's affected by the headache.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In most cases, Ménière's disease affects only one ear and can cause tinnitus and the feeling of ear fullness.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by high pressure in the brain without the presence of a tumor or other diseases. The symptoms may mimic those of a brain tumor and can include headache, vision problems, ringing in the ears (tinnitus), and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Symptoms may include hearing loss, tinnitus, dizziness, loss of balance, and brainstem compression.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, typically in the head, causing headache, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, vision complications, and could lead to blindness. Immediate treatment is crucial.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord that can cause weakness, coordination and balance difficulties, and other motor symptoms alongside visual and sensory symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault. Brain tumors can cause headaches, seizures, problems with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms that may include paralysis, speech problems, and others.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that's preceded by visual disturbances known as aura, alongside other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing tumors to form on nerve tissue, leading to a range of symptoms depending on the nerves affected.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that involves hearing and balance, leading to hearing loss and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare neurological disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks part of its peripheral nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Damage to nerves throughout the body in people with diabetes. It often leads to numbness, tingling, and pain, often starting in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A type of motor neuron disease, it involves the loss of voluntary muscle action and can result in difficulty speaking and swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge in a blood vessel in the brain that can leak or rupture, causing brain damage, paralysis, or other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread by ticks, can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms if not treated early.

diagnoses: Brain Tumor (including acoustic neuroma affecting the cochlear nerve)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe head pain followed or accompanied by sensory disturbances such as flashes of light, blind spots, tingling in the arms and legs, numbness, or difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system with symptoms including weakness, numbness, tingling sensations, and problems with coordination and balance.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it temporarily blocks blood flow to the brain causing symptoms similar to a stroke such as weakness and numbness on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A serious condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is cut off, leading to symptoms such as numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Schwannoma (Acoustic Neuroma)
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Symptoms may include hearing loss, ringing in the ear, dizziness, and loss of balance.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. Symptoms can lead to severe dizziness and a fluctuation in hearing loss over time.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. It can be benign or malignant and can cause symptoms including headaches, seizures, numbness, and weakness depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. Symptoms include numbness, tingling, and pain in the feet and hands.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, weight gain, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include headache, fatigue, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and a feeling of pressure deep inside the ear.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the cranial nerve that connects the inner ear with the brain, leading to hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances (such as scotoma and scintillation) and can include audio symptoms like tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Sudden Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SSHL)
diagnoses.description: An unexplained, rapid loss of hearing either all at once or over a few days, possibly accompanied by tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord that can cause visual disturbances (like scotoma), hearing loss, and tinnitus as a result of nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Otosclerosis
diagnoses.description: An abnormal bone growth in the middle ear that can cause hearing loss and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Labyrinthitis
diagnoses.description: An inner ear infection that can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease (AIED)
diagnoses.description: An immune system problem that attacks the inner ear, leading to progressive hearing loss and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Lobe Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A form of epilepsy that originates in the temporal lobe and can include auditory hallucinations such as tinnitus and changes in vision like scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Age-Related Macular Degeneration
diagnoses.description: A condition that can lead to loss of vision in the center of the visual field (macular scotoma) due to damage to the retina. While it primarily affects vision, patients with this condition often report tinnitus, likely due to the common risk factors and potential overlapping age-related changes affecting sensory systems.

diagnoses: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often on one side of the head.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it's characterized by temporary blockage of blood flow to the brain, causing short-lived symptoms similar to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system) leading to a wide range of symptoms, including muscle control, balance, and sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Its symptoms can be similar to those of a stroke or TIA, including headaches, speech problems, and sensory issues.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine where each headache is accompanied by temporary paralysis (hemiplegia) or neurological or sensory changes on one side of the body before or during the headache.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Venous Sinus Thrombosis (CVST)
diagnoses.description: A rare form of stroke that occurs when a blood clot forms in the brain's venous sinuses. This prevents blood from draining out of the brain, leading to increased pressure and symptoms like headache and neurological impairments.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Non-epileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.description: Seizures that occur as a psychological response to stress or trauma, rather than due to abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Symptoms can mimic those of an epileptic seizure but are not caused by electrical disruptions in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with associated cryoglobulinemia
Vasculitis (e.g., Henoch-Schönlein purpura, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) related to autoimmune diseases
Malignancies (e.g., lymphoma, leukemia, cancers metastasizing to pericardium)
Drug-induced lupus or other drug reactions

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, and internal organs. Nonscarring alopecia, hemolytic anemia, arthropathy, and synovitis are common manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic symptoms such as anemia and dermatological issues.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects the exocrine glands, leading to dry eyes and mouth, but can also cause arthropathy and hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: Refers to a group of autoimmune diseases, with SLE being the most common form, where the immune system attacks its own tissues causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. While not commonly associated with hemolytic anemia, autoimmune hemolytic anemia can coexist.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that may have features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, including symptoms such as arthropathy and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Anemia of Chronic Disease
diagnoses.description: Though typically presenting with normocytic anemia, this condition is often associated with chronic inflammatory, infectious, and autoimmune diseases that can also present with joint involvement and various skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A manifestation of SLE affecting blood vessels, leading to symptoms related to reduced blood flow, which may include skin rashes, alopecia, and joint pain. Hemolytic anemia may also be present.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, that can cause joint pain and swelling, skin and nail changes, and in some cases, systemic manifestations such as anemia.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition where the immune system attacks and destroys red blood cells, leading to anemia. It can occur in isolation or be part of other autoimmune diseases that might include joint and skin symptoms.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Hepatitis C)
Vasculitis (e.g., Microscopic Polyangiitis, Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Schizophrenia (considering the psychosis symptom, if not directly related to a physical illness)
Diabetic neuropathy (if the peripheral neuropathy is related to long-standing diabetes)
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune thrombocytopenia and autoimmune hemolytic anemia)
Vasculitis (such as Microscopic Polyangiitis or Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of various parts of the body. It can manifest with skin rash, joint pain and swelling (synovitis), low platelet count (thrombocytopenia), low lymphocyte count (lymphopenia), and inflammation of the heart's outer layer (pericarditis).

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disorder characterized by high fevers, rash, arthritis, and it can also involve thrombocytopenia, lymphopenia, and pericarditis. Synovitis is a common feature due to the arthritis component.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While primarily known for its effect on joints, it can also cause thrombocytopenia, and, more rarely, conditions like lymphopenia and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Dengue Fever
diagnoses.description: A mosquito-borne viral illness known to cause high fever, rash (often maculopapular), joint pain, and it can lead to significant thrombocytopenia and sometimes lymphopenia.

diagnoses.name: Chikungunya Fever
diagnoses.description: Another viral illness spread by mosquitoes. It presents with fever, joint pain with possible swelling (synovitis), rash, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral infection best known for its distinctive red rash. It's less commonly associated with joint involvement, thrombocytopenia, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 Infection
diagnoses.description: Known for causing fifth disease in children, which includes a distinctive facial rash ('slapped cheek' appearance), and can also cause joint pain (synovitis), thrombocytopenia, and lymphopenia in more severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by a tick. It's known for a rash that may start as maculopapular before becoming petechial, and can be accompanied by thrombocytopenia and less commonly, synovitis and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Ehrlichiosis
diagnoses.description: Another tick-borne bacterial disease that can present with a maculopapular rash, thrombocytopenia, and more rarely, symptoms like synovitis and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease with features of several connective tissue diseases including lupus, scleroderma, and myositis. Symptoms can include rash, joint pain (synovitis), lymphopenia, and occasionally, heart complications like pericarditis.

diagnoses: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (SJS/TEN) secondary to drug reaction
Chronic hepatitis B or C infection
Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, hepatitis C, endocarditis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with pericarditis, discoid rash, proteinuria (due to lupus nephritis), arthropathy, and leukopenia among various other possible manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Mainly known for causing arthropathy, but systemic involvement can lead to pericarditis and, rarely, leukopenia. Rash is less common, and proteinuria may signal secondary renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: This disease combines features of multiple autoimmune diseases including SLE, and can present with arthropathy, rash, proteinuria, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects moisture-producing glands but can have systemic manifestations including arthropathy and leukopenia. The association with pericarditis, discoid rash, and proteinuria is less common.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by skin thickening, it can also cause internal organ complications leading to proteinuria, arthropathy, and rarely pericarditis and hematological abnormalities such as leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This condition is known for its distinctive skin rash and muscle weakness. Systemic involvement can include arthropathy and, though less common, pericarditis and leukopenia. Proteinuria indicates renal involvement, which is rare.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain drugs can induce a lupus-like syndrome presenting with symptoms such as rash, arthropathy, and pericarditis. Leukopenia and proteinuria may also be observed.

diagnoses.name: Lupus-like Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A condition that mimics many of the clinical features of lupus but without fulfilling all the criteria for a definitive diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: It can occasionally cause skin manifestations (though not typically a discoid rash), arthropathy, and rarely pericarditis. Proteinuria can occur in the context of embolic renal disease and leukopenia may occasionally be seen.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis B or C with Mixed Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.rationale: These viral infections can cause mixed cryoglobulinemia, which can lead to a vasculitis presenting with rash, arthropathy, proteinuria, and potentially other systemic symptoms.

Primary Immunodeficiencies (e.g., Common Variable Immune Deficiency)
Medication-induced conditions (e.g., due to chemotherapy agents)
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia
